summary.seg: The principal contents of this manuscript are two long compilations of medical recipes and cures. The second of these is in large part extracted from the body of work by the surgeon and author John Arderne (1307/08-after 1377), the so-called Liber medicinarum sive receptorum liber medicinalium ('Book of medicines or book of medical recipes') (see Peter Jones's introduction to Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.2.49 for further details). Arderne is better known for his description of successful operations to treat anal fistulas. The first compilation, meanwhile, is anonymous - there is no evidence here to connect it with Arderne – and is entitled Radix medicinarum in its closing rubric. It is apparently known only in this manuscript. Like Arderne, its author-compiler was an Englishman, and was evidently well-acquainted with important medical authorities, which familiarity he shows off in the prologue. Using a well-worn modesty topos, he explained the reasons for undertaking the work, beginning with a quotation from the Practica brevis of the Salernitan writer Iohannes Platearius II (fl. 1090-1120) that rather self-consciously aligns his own work with that of his illustrious predecessor:

seg.hi: Because, as Platearius says in the first [book] of his Practica, 'He becomes a friend, who bends to the wishes of his friends', and because, dearest and most beloved friends, you asked, through the grace of God, that it be carried out quickly by me, it has been undertaken by me with the greatest diligence to address every single part of the body, by dealing in succession with the head all the way to the soles of the feet, and for them the simple and also compound medicines, and the sources of illnesses, towards their [i.e. the medicines'] more effective use.

summary.seg: The writer affirms the importance of paying close attention to the study of a patient's urine and its four regions, which he explained correspond to four regions of the body: the first of these is the 'circulus' (the upper layer of urine when it is examined in a flask), which relates to the head and wherein all of its ailments are signified. Following the common head-to-toe order of recipe compilations, he explains that the head and its contents, as the first region of the body, will be the first in order, along with all of its related maladies, 'and thus I descend, describing in detail, all the way to the last region'. The first section does indeed deal in successive chapters with allopecia, hair loss, greying, dandruff, sores, 'fanis' ('an ailment of the head when pus emerges from the head like honey'), headache, migraine, lethargy, frenzy, mania and melacholy, epilepsy, apoplexy, spasms, paralysis, drunkenness, catarrh, sleeplessness, sneezing, watering and various other problems of the eyes such as redness or spots, numerous ailments of the ears, nose and teeth, bad breath, tongue problems, and freckles.

However, the system breaks down thereafter, with the final chapters of this section addressing coughs, asthma, breathlessness and complaints of the heart and breasts. While the marginal rubric on f. 43v states that it marks the beginning of the 'Secunda Regio', the rubric in the text itself reads 'De infirmitatibus tertie regionis, que est a diafragmate usque ad renes'. The section on the kidneys begins on f. 59r, with genito-urinary and obstetric matters following from f. 61r, before turning without a break to different types of leprosy from f. 63v ('lepra', 'leonina', 'tiria', 'elephancia'), then arthritis, morphew, apostemes and finally verrucas. The section on surgery runs from ff. 65v-69r, with a final grouping of miscellaneous cures whose end is marked 'Explicit cirurgia'. The final section is on fevers. John of Burgundy is cited in chapter 18, on pestilential fevers (f. 86v). Each chapter proceeds more or less systematically: for example, Chapter 10 in the first section, 'De frenesis' ('Concerning delirium/madness', ff. 15v-16v), describes the illness and then its signs, as well others that indicate the disease is incurable or that death is near. It then provides potential cures, and advises what food and drink should be given (this included pumpkin seeds, almond milk, wheatbread, purslain, and lettuce with a sour dressing).

At the beginning of the text, the writer lists six authoritative sources from which his work was compiled, the first three of whom were connected with the medical school at Salerno: Constantinus Africanus in his Pantegni and Viaticum, Platearius, 'Gerard' (perhaps Gerardus Bituricensis, who glossed the Viaticum), 'Roger' (perhaps Roger Baron, author of a Practica medicinae), and Ricardus Anglicus. 'Seventh, and last,' he concludes, 'I will write down everything tested by myself and all of my secrets, and also everything which I have seen through others in my time, whether foreigners or Englishmen...'. However, other sources are mentioned besides those listed in the prologue. In the chapter on frenesis, Avicenna, Serapion and Razes are also referred to, though these are likely second-hand quotations culled from another source text. 'Magister Johannes arderne londoniensis' is given as a source for a remedy for haemorrhoids (f. 53v). On occasion, the writer acknowledges the limits of his own knowledge. Having described a cure for leprosy, he admitted: 'But I am not experienced thus far, if you are able or wish to attempt it' ('Sed ego non sum expertus adhuc potestis si vultis attemptare'; f. 65v).

Elsewhere, the author records a cure for catarrh that he saw used by a 'Master Marcus' in London (f. 21v; this too may not be original), and mentions another for the same from the anonymous antidotary text, Pomum ambre. Perhaps one of the writer's 'secrets' is found in the section on cough or tightness in the chest ('contra tussum et stricturam pectoris'). He claimed to have successfully used a remedy on himself at Aylesford on Christmas Day, when he suffered from a severe obstruction of the lungs from the thickening and clotting of his breath ('hoc probavi in meipso apud aylesforde quia in die natali domini habui grave epilacionem pulmonis ex viscoso et coagulatio flante'). The following morning, taking after lunch six of the pills described above, his lungs were cleared. Aylesford might be the Carmelite priory founded in Kent in the mid-13th century and it is possible that the writer was himself a friar. Members of this and other mendicant orders are known to have studied and practised medicine, as Peter Jones has recently illustrated. Indeed, there are references elsewhere to direct contact with friars, such as in the section on treating nosebleeds (f. 30r). The writer describes how he proved a cure at Stamford on a friar, when nothing else had accomplished it ('Hoc probaui apud Staunforde in uno fratre quando nihil profecit illud'), and also received another from a Brother John of London in the Winchester diocese. Elsewhere, he cites a 'Brother John Holm' (f. 33r), perhaps a mistaken reference to William Holme, Franciscan friar and author of Tractatus de medicinis (c. 1400) and De simplicibus medicinis (c. 1415).

The two main texts are on discrete groups of quires – the Radix ending in Quire 11, the excerpts from John Arderne beginning in Quire 12 – but the presence of numerous content markers by a variety of 15th- and perhaps early 16th-century hands, some of which made notes in both sections, confirms that the two parts of the manuscript were bound together from an early stage. Indeed, there is evidence to indicate that they were in fact produced together: their leaves are each frame-ruled for two columns, in the same manner and to similar overall dimensions (with slight differences in column width), and the hand responsible for each appears also to be the same (albeit executing a somewhat larger module of script in the second section). Regrettably, the manuscript has suffered badly from damp and its current binding from 1954 is rather tight at the gutter; this unfortunate combination has caused many of the leaves to deteriorate where they bend as the book is used. A limitation on the degree to which the manuscript may be opened safely has meant that the text immediately adjacent to the gutter is sometimes obscured and could not be captured during digitisation. This also prevented further analysis of the parchment sewing guards wrapped around the outside and inside of the spinefold of each quire. Many are blank, but some bear text, and as is often the case they appear to have been recycled from a contemporary document of some sort. On the longer ones, some of the writing is legible and two snippets in particular are worth mentioning – references to the parish church of 'Westleueton' (probably Westleton) (ff. 65v×66r) and to a monastery dedicated to St Mary at 'Wyveton' (perhaps Binham Priory, near Wiveton) (ff. 69v×70r) – which together are suggestive of a Norfolk provenance at some point in the manuscript's early history.

Dr James Freeman
Medieval Manuscripts Specialist
Cambridge University Library
(My thanks to Peter Jones for comments on and additions to an earlier draft.)

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.

signatures.p: At the University Library, Arabic numbers (1-17) have been added in pencil on the lower right-hand corners of the first rectos of quires between ff. 10-144; based on previous collation that considered ff. 2-9 as one quire (a1) that is missing its 10th leaf.

collation.note: NB: The collation in this catalogue record deviates from the modern collation supplied in the manuscript in that it identifies ff. 2-9 as Quire 1 (instead of a1). Consequently, the subsequent quire numbers used in this catalogue record are incremented by one from the designations visible in the manuscript (e.g. Quire 1 in the manuscript is 2 in this record). The collation in this catalogue record also deviates from existing descriptions in that it divides the manuscript into two codicological units. Although there are many similarities between the handwriting, decoration, layout, and watermarks in both parts that suggest that they may have been produced in a single copying endeavour, they are treated separately in this catalogue record in order to give a detailed account of their particular aspects.

supportDesc.condition: The lower margins and halves of ff. 62r-144v have been significantly affected by damp, but without rendering text illegible.

additions.note: Folios [iii] verso-1v contain a collection of five Middle English recipes added by 15th-century cursive hands that cannot be found in the main parts of the manuscript. Two of the English recipes (one for burns and scalds and one for an ointment) are attributed to R.B., possibly referring to the Oxford Franciscan friar Roger Bacon (see Connolly, Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (2009), p. 21) or to the R. Belis mentioned at the end of the final recipe.
University Library note inscribed on f. [vi] recto: Dd.5.54 taken out and bound separately / 1901 July 27 / F.J. (i.e. Francis Jenkinson).

binding.p: Quarter-leather binding with marbled paper covers and blank pastedowns by (?) Gray of Cambridge in 1954, as suggested by a blue stamp on the inside upper cover: Repaired by .GR. binding guild, with the handwritten note: 83/5 : 1954.

Previously bound together with Dd.5.54 (a catalogue of books at St John's College from about 1620): the two volumes were separated on 27 July 1901, as per a handwritten note on f. [vi] recto: Dd.5.54 taken out and bound separately 1901 July 27 F.J.. On f. [iii] recto of MS Dd.5.53 there is still an early classmark for the joint manuscripts: 53-54.

provenance.p: Unknown owner, their erased ownership inscription in a 15th-century script on f. [iii] verso: Liber Gilbert [...].
Unknown owner, their faded user inscription in a late 15th- or early 16th-century script on f. [iii] verso: Per me Bartho[lomeus] A[...].
Unknown owner, their inscription of a price that may refer to the sum paid for the manuscript at the top of f. 1r: Precium [?a] xiijs iiijd.
John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : no. 31 (inscribed on f. 1r) in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697).

history.acquisition: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 : donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736 on the inside of the upper cover.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on Catalogue of the Manuscripts preserved in the Library of the University of Cambridge 5 vols (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1856-1867), I, pp. 273-274, Margaret Connolly Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo), Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist 19 (Woodbridge: Brewer, 2009), pp. 20-21, and an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS Dd.5.53, ff. 2-89

msItem.title: Synonima herbarum
msItem.incipit: 2r Artemisia calida est et sicca in tertio gradu anglice mugworth
msItem.explicit: 2r Amfericon id est herba perforata herba Johannis
msItem.note: Added in a 15th-century hand that is different from that of the main part of the manuscript. Apparently ends imperfectly.

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.note: Added by a 15th-century hand that is different from that of the main part of the manuscript.

msItem.title: Medical recipe to treat haemorrhoids
msItem.note: Added in the 15th century by a hand that is different from that on ff. 10r-144r.

msItem.title: Alchemical recipe
msItem.note: Added in the 15th century by the same hand that copied the previous recipe.

msItem.title: Radix medicinarum
msItem.incipit: 10r Quoniam ut ait Platearius in principio sue practice: Amicum induit qui partibus amicorum condescendit
msItem.explicit: 89r Nunc finem feci penitet me si male scripsi.
msItem.note: Large medical compilation divided in three books (Book 1: 10r-43v; Book 2: 43v-69r; Book 3 69r-89r, with a short preface (10r), previously tentatively attributed to John Arderne.

msItem.title: Unfinished list of chapters
msItem.note: Added in the 15th century by a different hand.

msItem.title: List of chapters
msItem.note: Added in the 17th century, ending: finish τέλως.

supportDesc.support:
Paper, folded in quarto.
Folios 2-89: Bull's head with five-pointed star .

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in decorative banderols in the right lower corners of the last versos of quires throughout the manuscript

supportDesc.condition: The lower margins and halves of ff. 62r-89v have been significantly affected by damp, but without rendering text illegible.

p.seg: Ruled in ink, frame only. Double columns. 30-34 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: ff. 10r-89r have been written by a single scribe (perhaps the same scribe that copied Part 2) writing in a Gothic cursive script with both Secretary Anglicana features.
The list of herbs on f. 2r has been written by a single scribe in a cursive with Anglicana and Secretary features, which is the same hand that copied the unifinished list of chapters on f. 89r.

decoNote.p: Drawing of a medical instrument (clister) in brown ink on ff. 88v.
Spaces for large (2- to 6-line) initials have been left blank throughout (but guide letters are present).
Two large initials J in red ink on ff. 57v and 65v.
Capitals in brown or red ink decorated with cadels.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS Dd.5.53, ff. 90-144

msItem.title: Medical compilation
msItem.author: John Arderne
msItem.rubric: 90r Extracta de libro Magistri Iohanni Arderne in practica sua contra omnem guttam unguentum probatum etcaetera
msItem.explicit: 144r De escula. Escula dura bona set mollia sunt meliora.
msItem.note: Contains charms for speeding the delivery of child 107r-107v, for staunching blood 114v, against spasms 117v, and against fevers 122v.
A medical compilation with works from John Arderne's Liber medicinarum sive receptorum liber medicinalium, but also including other items, as can be seen from the items listed below.

listBibl.bibl: Jones and Olsan (2015), p. 421 n. 37 [edition of the charm for speeding the delivery of a child].

msItem.title: Tract on the Twelve Astrological Signs of the Zodiac
msItem.incipit: 122v [A]ries est masculi generis calidus et siccus
msItem.explicit: 124r Qui nascitur in hoc signo gloriosus erit

msItem.title: Tract on the moon's position in the Zodiac
msItem.rubric: 124r Nota regulam ad cognoscendum in quo signo inveneris lunam omni die
msItem.incipit: 124r Si vis scire in quo signo sit luna
msItem.explicit: 124r Et in primo subsequentis signi. vnde versus.
msItem.finalRubric: 124r Etatem lune dupla post addito quinque. Quinque dabis signo quo lune cepit origo.

msItem.title: De Retardatione accidentium senectutis
msItem.author: Roger Bacon
msItem.rubric: 125v De retardatione senectutis secundum Rogerum Bakon
msItem.incipit: 125v Dicit Haly quod caro tiri comesta
msItem.note: Perhaps an abbreviated paraphrase from Roger Bacon.

listBibl.bibl: De retardatione accidentium senectutis, ed. by A.G. Little and E. Withington, Opera hactenus inedita Rogeri Baconi, 9 (Oxford: Clarendon, 1928), p. xvii.

msItem.title: Treatise on the medical virtues of stones (lapidary)
msItem.rubric: 128v Incipit tractatus de virtutibus lapidis preciosorum etcaetera
msItem.explicit: 137v Et non tantum de periculo pertumescat etceterae

msItem.title: Treatise on the medical virtues of herbs (herbal)
msItem.rubric: 137v De amilo [? anulo] et alijs speciebus etcaetera
msItem.explicit: 142v Gaudet epar spodio carparius splen stoma galanga / Pulmo liquericia mace cor cerebrum quoque musca.

msItem.title: Regimen sanitatis Salernitanum
msItem.incipit: 142v Anglorum regi scripsit tota scola Salerni
msItem.explicit: 144r De Escula: Escula dura bona set mollia sunt meliora

msItem.title: Charm for a bite from a rabid dog
msItem.incipit: 144r scribe hec verba in pane videlicet tripartita pega et sega et dera et fema
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in a different 15th-century hand than that of the main part.

msItem.title: Charm for a bite from a rabid dog
msItem.incipit: 144r alius: Calibus aribus Rives Revas opulusque
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by a 16th-century hand.

Paper, folded in quarot.

p.seg: Ruled in ink (except for a few pages that have been ruled in blindpoint: ff. 90r-91v, and 141v-142r), frame only. Double columns. 30-32 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: ff. 90-144r have been written by a single scribe (perhaps the scribe that copied Part 1) writing in a Gothic cursive script with both Secretary Anglicana features.

decoNote.p: Drawing of a medical instrument (clister) in red ink on f. 95v.
Large (2 lines) initial with penwork decoration and pen-flourishing in brown ink on f. 90r ; an unfinished one on f. 97v, where the initial has only been outlined in black ink.
Large (2- to 6-line) plain initials in red ink.
Plain 1-line capitals highglighted with red ink.
